ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class helped me develop the basics of speaking, reading, and writing/typing Hebrew.
Learned to read and write in Hebrew, as well as vocabulary and the basics of grammar. Covered a surprisingly large amount!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: The class is very well organized, with consistent homework that lets you get into a rhythm. We get consistent, daily practice with all the ways we use language--reading, handwriting, typing, listening, speaking. Vocabulary and grammar concepts build at a steady pace. The course is fast-paced but gives a lot of support and opportunities to practice, and the asynchronous day in the middle of the week lets you review anything you didn't understand from earlier in the week. It's 1.5 credits but the homework load is very reasonable. It's hard to imagine a better introduction to a language! Weaknesses: none.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone looking to learn Hebrew for the first time or enhance minimal knowledge.
Yes - fun, not too much work, you'll learn a lot.
I'd highly recommend this course to someone who wants to learn Hebrew from scratch, or from little prior knowledge. You'll be surprised how much you've learned by the end of the semester!
